Highly selective and stable PdNi catalyst derived from layered double hydroxides for partial hydrogenation of acetylene Qiu Jin Yufei He Manyu Miao Chaoyang Guan Yiyun Du Junting Feng ⁎ Dianqing Li State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 1064451007; fax: +86 1064425385. Graphical abstract An effective and versatile synthetic approach is presented to prepare highly selective and stable bimetallic PdNi catalyst for selective hydrogenation of acetylene. NiMgAl-layered double hydroxide (LDH) was synthesized by separate nucleation and aging steps, followed by the introduction of PdCl4 2− to obtain the catalyst precursor. The positive charge of NiMgAl-LDH layer offers an opportunity to realize uniform dispersion of PdCl4 2−, which facilitates the formation of bimetallic PdNi nanoparticles. Upon thermal reduction of PdCl4 2−/NiMgAl-LDH precursor, highly dispersed bimetallic PdNi/MgAl-MMO catalyst was obtained. As comparison, MMO-supported PdNi catalyst was also prepared by the co-impregnation and sol-immobilization method. The catalyst derived from LDH precursor exhibited much higher activity and selectivity toward ethene than that prepared by other two methods, which could be attributed to smaller metal particle size and stronger interaction between two metals. Furthermore, because of preferable structure stability, this catalyst also possessed higher stability of activity. Preferable structure stability of the catalyst could be due to the net trap effect of MgAl-MMO microcrystals stemming from LDH precursor, which provided fixed positions for the PdNi nanoparticles during the reaction. Keywords PdNi Layered double hydroxides Trace acetylene Selective hydrogenation 1 Introduction Ethene is an important raw material for industrial products, particularly for polyethene production. Typically, the ethene from cracking of naphtha contains about 0.1–1% of acetylene as an impurity which could poison the catalysts and degrade the product quality [1]. Partial hydrogenation is one of the typical approaches to remove trace amounts of acetylene in ethene [2]. Pd-based catalysts are the most studied catalysts for the partial hydrogenation of unsaturated C–C bonds [3]. In principle, the hydrogenation activity and selectivity are related to the binding strength and bonding orientation of the unsaturated bond on the catalyst surface, both of which can be varied by modifying the electronic properties and geometric structures of the catalysts through the formation of bimetallic catalysts [4]. The Pd-based bimetallic catalysts typically display higher selectivity than the corresponding monometallic catalysts [5]. López and Vargas-Fuentes [6] found that there were two aspects of influences caused by the introduction of secondary metal (such as Ag, Au, Ga, Cu, and Zn) on the catalytic performance in partial hydrogenation of acetylene through the DFT calculation. Studt et al. [7] investigated the effect of alloying Pd with Ag in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene. Yarulin et al. [8] studied the effect of second metal in Pd-based catalyst in alkynol hydrogenation. As for the geometric effect, the addition of secondary metal increased the number of isolated Pd atoms, which would restrain the formation of multiple bonding ethylidene intermediates, carbide and oligomer. In addition, the electronic effect changed the adsorption/desorption properties of hydrogen over the surface of catalysts. These theoretical calculation results are well consistent with the reported experimental results. Preliminary research by our group [9] showed that bimetallic Pd-Ga/MgO-Al2O3 catalyst possessed higher ethene selectivity but slightly lower activity than monometallic Pd/MgO-Al2O3 catalyst. Huang et al. [10] found that Pd-Ag catalyst exhibited much higher selectivity but lower activity than Pd catalyst. The Pd-Cu catalyst also showed higher styrene selectivity and maintained similar activity to that of Pd catalyst [11]. Different from the above mentioned bimetallic Pd-based catalysts, bimetallic PdNi catalyst was reported to exhibit not only higher selectivity but also higher activity for 1,3-butadiene hydrogenation [12]. During the hydrogenation of alkyne to alkene process, the first step is the dissociative adsorption of H2 on surface, the rate determining step of the reaction, which has a high energy cost on Pd and Ni. Bridier et al. studied the hydrogenation performance over individual Pd and Ni [13]. Pd catalyst produces mainly alkane, followed by oligomers and to a minor extent alkene. Although continuous CO feeding could suppress over-hydrogenation, the yield to oligomers increased significantly. Ni catalyst displays a much higher selectivity to alkene than Pd. Lee et al. [14] investigated the effects of Ni addition on the performance of Pd-Ag/Al2O3 catalysts in selective hydrogenation of acetylene. The Ni-modified Pd-Ag catalyst showed both higher activity and selectivity than Ni-free Pd-Ag catalyst. Therefore, rational design and synthesis of supported PdNi bimetallic catalyst are of great importance on simultaneously increasing the selectivity and activity for the partial hydrogenation of acetylene. The frequently used methods of preparing bimetallic catalysts are co-impregnation and sol-immobilization [15–18]. However, the active components are inhomogeneously dispersed on the support when using the co-impregnation method due to the surface tension of the impregnation solution. Besides, the weak interaction between support and metals further leads to the migration and aggregation during subsequent calcination at high temperature. The alternative approach, sol-immobilization method, could improve the metal dispersion to a certain extent. It involves the synthesis of colloidal sols, in which the nanoparticles are stabilized in solution by the adhesion of specific surfactant or ligand molecules and therefore achieve higher metal dispersion. However, the stabilizer remained on the surface of catalyst would influence the catalytic performance and removal of these stabilizing molecules is still problematic. Therefore, developing a new kind of method to prepare supported bimetallic catalyst with high metal dispersion and strong interaction between metals and the support could be valuable. Layered double hydroxides (LDH) are a class of anionic clays whose structure is based on brucite (Mg(OH)2)-like layers in which some of the divalent cations have been replaced by trivalent ions giving positively charged sheets [19]. LDH have a general formula [MII 1-x MIII(OH)2] x+(A n−) x/n ·yH2O [20]. The identities of the divalent and trivalent cations (MII and MIII, respectively) and the interlayer anion (A n−) together with the variety of the stoichiometric coefficient (x) may be varied over a wide range, giving rise to a large class of isostructural materials. Because of the lattice orientation effect of LDH, cations (MII and MIII) could be homogenously dispersed in the layer [21]. Due to the net trap confinement effect of LDH, the aggregation of active metals could be reduced. In this work, we intended to introduce Ni2+ into the layer of LDH to prepare NiMgAl-LDH precursor. Because of the roughly equal radius of Ni2+ and Mg2+, Ni2+ could replace a portion of Mg2+ to form NiMgAl-LDH with stable structure. The dispersive and isolated effect of Mg2+ and Al3+ enable Ni2+ achieving a high dispersion in the layer. Introduction of the Pd component was then effected by impregnation, in which positive charge in LDH layer interacted with negative charge in PdCl4 2− realizing uniform dispersion of PdCl4 2−. The net trap confinement effect offers the opportunity to form highly dispersed PdNi nanoparticles catalyst supported on MgAl-mixed metal oxide (MgAl-MMO) by the following co-reduction of PdCl4 2−/NiMgAl-LDH precursor. The synthetic schematic diagram of the bimetallic L-PdNi catalysts is shown in Fig. 1 . As comparison, the supported PdNi catalysts were also prepared by the co-impregnation and sol-immobilization method. The discrepancy in the structure and catalytic performance of the catalysts obtained by the three different methods will be discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, Al(NO3)3·9H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Na2CO3, NaOH, PdCl2, and NaCl were of A.R. grade and used without further purification. The water used in all the experiments was deionized with an electrical conductivity less than 10−6 Scm−1. 2.2 PdNi catalyst prepared by LDH precursor method NiMgAl-LDH precursor was synthesized by separate nucleation and aging steps [22]. A 70.0ml solution containing 7.4045g Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, 5.4169g Al(NO3)3·9H2O and 0.1260g Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was added into a 100ml beaker. Simultaneously, a 70.0ml solution containing 3.0610g Na2CO3 and 2.7725g NaOH was also prepared. The nucleation process was performed by pouring these two solutions into the colloid mill quickly followed by the crystal growth procedure carried out at 120°C with stirring for 6h. After the reaction, the samples were washed with deionized water and then dried for 10h at 70°C. Subsequently, NiMgAl-LDH was obtained. Introduction of Pd was achieved through the impregnation way. 1.200g NiMgAl-LDH precursor was rapidly put into a 50ml beaker containing 1.365ml pre-made Na2PdCl4 solution (the concentration of Pd2+ was 0.05moll−1) and 10.0ml deionized water. The beaker was shaken gently for 1h to impregnate completely. After washed with deionized water, the samples were placed in constant temperature incubator at 70°C for 10h, denoted as PdCl4 2−/NiMgAl-LDH. The reduction of the PdCl4 2−/NiMgAl-LDH precursor was processed in 10% H2 in argon at 550°C for 4h, and the heating rate was 2°Cmin−1 to obtain bimetallic PdNi/MgAl-MMO catalyst, denoted as L-PdNi catalyst. 2.3 PdNi catalyst prepared by co-impregnation method As comparison, PdNi catalyst was also obtained by the co-impregnation method using MgAl-LDH as the support. MgAl-LDH support was prepared in the same way with NiMgAl-LDH except the absence of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O. Pd and Ni were introduced into the sample by co-impregnation method. 1.200g MgAl-LDH support was rapidly added into a 50ml beaker containing 1.365ml pre-made Na2PdCl4 solution (the concentration of Pd2+was 0.050moll−1) and 10.0ml Ni(NO3)2 solution (the concentration of Ni2+was 0.020moll−1). The beaker was shaken gently for 1h to impregnate completely. After washed with deionized water, the samples were placed in constant temperature incubator at 70°C for 10h, denoted as (PdCl4 2−-Ni2+)/MgAl-LDH. The reduction of the (PdCl4 2−-Ni2+)/MgAl-LDH precursor was processed in the same condition of PdCl4 2−/NiMgAl-LDH precursor to obtain PdNi/MMO catalyst, denoted as I-PdNi catalyst. 2.4 PdNi catalyst prepared by sol-immobilization method To an aqueous Na2PdCl4 and Ni(NO3)2 mixed solution, the required amount of PVA solution (1%wt.) was added (PVA/(Ni+Pd) (wt./wt.)=1.2). A freshly prepared solution of NaBH4 (0.1M, NaBH4/(Ni+Pd) (mol/mol)=5) was then added to form a dark-brown sol. After 30min of sol generation, the colloid was immobilized by adding MgAl-LDH support under vigorous stirring conditions. The amount of support material required was calculated so as to have a total final metal loading of 2% wt. After 1h, the slurry was filtered and the catalyst washed thoroughly with acetone and deionized water and dried at 70°C for 10h. The obtained PdNi/MgAl-LDH catalyst was denoted as Sol-PdNi. 2.5 Characterizations Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer using Cu Kɑ radiation (λ =0.154nm) in the 2θ ranges of 3–70° with a scan speed of 10°min−1. The morphology and lattice fringes of the samples were examined using a JEOL JEM-2100 high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM). Surface elemental analysis was performed using an ESCALAB250 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) equipped with Mg Kɑ radiation. C 1s peak at 285eV was used as a calibration peak. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR), H2, NH3 and C2H4 temperature programmed desorption (TPD) were conducted on a Micrometric ChemiSorb 2750 chemisorption instrument with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For TPR experiments, about 0.1g of samples were loaded in a quartz reactor and heated in He for 60min at 120°C, then carried out with a heating ramp rate of 10°Cmin−1 in a stream of 10% H2 in Ar to 800°C, with a total flow rate of 25mlmin−1. For H2-TPD and C2H4-TPD experiments, 0.1g catalysts precursors were reduced at 550°C in the quartz reactor for 1h, flushed with Ar (for H2-TPD) or He (for C2H4-TPD) for 1h to remove the residual H2 and cooled to room temperature. The samples were then treated with probe molecules with the flow rate of 40mlmin−1 at room temperature until the adsorption was saturated. Weakly adsorbed probe molecules were removed by flowing Ar or He for 30min, and then the desorption process was recorded from room temperature to 600°C (H2-TPD) and 300°C (C2H4-TPD) in Ar or He flow at a rate of 10°Cmin−1. For NH3-TPD experiment, 0.1g samples were pre-treated in He for 60min at 120°C, followed by the adsorption of probe molecules NH3 (40mlmin−1) at room temperature until saturated, after which the samples were flushed with He for 30min to remove weakly adsorbed species from the sample surface. The experimental error in TPD temperature is ±3°C, according to repeated tests. TPO analyses were also carried out on catalyst samples. After a time-on-stream hydrogenation process, the catalysts were transferred into the quartz tube followed by heating in He flow for 60min at 120°C. The gas composition was then switched to O2, and the temperature was increased to 550°C with a ramp rate of 10°Cmin−1. 2.6 Catalytic measurements Partial hydrogenation of acetylene was carried out in a Xian Quan WFS-3015 fixed-bed micro-reactor over the temperature range of 30–70°C, with a space velocity (GHSV) of 10,056h−1 and the relative pressure of 0.2MPa. About 25mg of catalyst was loaded at the center of the reactor. The reactant stream contained 0.962% acetylene in ethene and the H2/C2H2 ratio was 2. The reactants and products were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) with a flame ionization detector online using a PLOT capillary column (0.53×50mm). Before acquisition of the data (points related to the studied catalysts under different experimental conditions), at least five tested for point were executed in order to obtain reproducible values, and carbon balance determined from the effluent gas was 100±0.5%. Acetylene conversion and selectivity toward ethene are defined as follows [23]: Acetylene conversion = C 2 H 2 ( inlet ) − C 2 H 2 ( outlet ) C 2 H 2 ( inlet ) Selectivity toward ethene = C 2 H 4 ( outlet ) − C 2 H 4 ( inlet ) C 2 H 2 ( inlet ) − C 2 H 2 ( outlet ) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD and TPR of catalyst precursors NiMgAl-LDH and MgAl-LDH were prepared by the separate nucleation and aging steps using sodium carbonate as a precipitant. The powder XRD patterns are shown in Fig. S1. Both NiMgAl-LDH and MgAl-LDH displayed the characteristic reflections of LDH structure with a series of (003) and (006) peaks at low angle, indicating the formation of LDH [24]. Peaks at around 2θ =60° are corresponding to (110) facet of the LDH layer. The lattice parameter a =2d 110 reflects the interplanar spacing [25]. Due to larger radius of Ni2+ than Mg2+, the value of NiMgAl-LDH (0.305nm) was slightly higher than that of MgAl-LDH (0.301nm), suggesting that Ni2+ was successfully introduced into the LDH layer [26]. Furthermore, compared with MgAl-LDH, the peaks of NiMgAl-LDH representing (003) and (006) facets located at around 10° and 24° shifted to lower angles. This change was due to the different water content in the interlayer of the two materials [27]. The distinction could be vanished by the following thermal process. To obtain appropriate co-reduction temperature of the catalyst precursors, TPR experiments were performed over PdCl4 2−/NiMgAl-LDH and PdCl4 2−-Ni2+/MgAl-LDH precursor. Pristine MgAl-LDH and NiMgAl-LDH support were taken to be the reference objects and the corresponding profiles are shown in Fig. 2 . Considering the convenience of analysis, the TPR profiles are divided to two regions. The pristine MgAl-LDH support in region II has only one weak peak, which is due to the reduction of interlayer anion of LDH. Compared with MgAl-LDH (2a), the peak of NiMgAl-LDH (2c) in region II exhibits much higher intensity, suggesting that the peak in region II contains the reduction of both interlayer anion and partial Ni2+ in the layer of NiMgAl-LDH [28]. For PdCl4 2−/NiMgAl-LDH (2d), a weak peak in region I and a strong peak in region II are observed. The peak in region I at around 105°C is corresponding to the reduction of partial Pd2+ which has weak interaction with Ni species [29]. The peak in region II at about 450°C could be ascribed to the co-reduction of Ni2+ in the LDH layers and residual Pd2+, resulting in the formation of bimetallic PdNi particles. Different with PdCl4 2−/NiMgAl-LDH, the reduction peak intensity of PdCl4 2−-Ni2+/MgAl-LDH (2b) in region I is much higher which could be ascribed to larger amount of Pd2+ with weak interaction of Ni species. Additionally, the reduced Pd facilitates the spillover of H2, which is subsequently released, further increasing the intensity of the peak in region I [30]. On the basis of the TPR results, 550°C was employed to obtain the bimetallic PdNi/MMO catalyst. 3.2 Catalytic performance of partial hydrogenation of acetylene The catalytic performance of the three catalysts (I-PdNi, L-PdNi and Sol-PdNi) prepared by different methods in partial hydrogenation of acetylene is shown in Fig. 3 . Catalytic activity is defined as the rate of acetylene consumption. Fig. 3A shows that the activity was in the order of Sol-PdNi>L-PdNi>I-PdNi. In detail, acetylene conversion of Sol-PdNi catalyst at 30°C was 15%, and reached 95% when the reaction temperature increased to 70°C. L-PdNi catalyst showed only 5% conversion at 30°C but the similar conversion as Sol-PdNi when the temperature reached 70°C. For I-PdNi catalyst, the maximum conversion of acetylene was about 85% at 70°C, which was the lowest at the same temperature. The difference in the activity for the three catalysts could be related to the particle size of active component and the interplay between Pd and Ni in the catalysts, which will be discussed in the following section. As shown in Fig. 3B, the selectivity toward ethene over the three catalysts decreased in the order of L-PdNi/MMO>I-PdNi/MMO>Sol-PdNi/LDH. When the reaction temperature ranged from 30 to 70°C, the selectivity over L-PdNi/MMO catalyst decreased steadily, from almost 100% to about 75%. However, the selectivity over I-PdNi catalyst decreased sharply when the temperature reached 60°C and further decreased to 55% at 70°C. The preferable ethene selectivity of L-PdNi catalyst compared to I-PdNi catalyst could be due to stronger synergistic effect of bimetallic PdNi including geometric and electronic effect [9]. As for Sol-PdNi catalyst, the selectivity decreased rapidly from almost 80% to only 15% with the temperature increasing. Poor selectivity of the Sol-PdNi catalyst could be ascribed to the different nature of the support from that of L-PdNi and I-PdNi. For the Sol-PdNi catalyst, bimetallic PdNi nanoparticles were formed before immobilizing onto the support of MgAl-LDH. The obtained PdNi/MgAl-LDH catalyst was tested directly without any further thermal process. While both I-PdNi and L-PdNi catalyst precursors were experienced thermal reduction procedure in which the MgAl-LDH support was transformed into MgAl-MMO. In order to confirm this speculation, the support of I-PdNi catalyst was reconstructed to MgAl-LDH without any variations of bimetallic PdNi nanoparticles by utilizing the memory effect of LDH. Compared with I-PdNi catalyst, an obviously decrease of selectivity is observed over the reconstructed I-PdNi/MgAl-LDH catalyst as shown in Fig. S2, suggesting that the MgAl-LDH support is negative to ethene desorption. Besides, Sol-PdNi catalyst experienced the same thermal process to transform the support from LDH to MMO and the catalytic performance is also given in Fig. 3. The acetylene conversion over Sol-PdNi/MMO is significantly lower than that of Sol-PdNi/LDH, L-PdNi/MMO, and I-PdNi/MMO catalysts, which could be attributed to the aggregation of metal particles during the thermal treatment. While the selectivity of ethene over Sol-PdNi/MMO catalyst increased after thermal treatment, indicating the MMO support is superior to LDH for the ethene selectivity. Except for the nature of support, the particle size of metals also has a decisive role in the selectivity. Generally, the increase of particle size could lead to the decrease of ethane selectivity. In this case, the support effect overwhelms the particle size effect. In addition, because the ethene selectivity decreased sharply when the acetylene conversion approached 100%, it is necessary to investigate the selectivity at a fixed conversion over different catalysts. Fig. 3C shows that the selectivity of Sol-PdNi, I-PdNi, and L-PdNi catalysts is 25%, 55% and 80%, respectively, at the acetylene conversion of 85%, indicating that the bimetallic PdNi catalyst obtained by LDH precursor method has preferable selectivity than that obtained by both co-impregnation and sol-immobilization method. 3.3 The study of structure–performance relationship 3.3.1 Particle size and XPS analysis of bimetals in catalysts It has been suggested that acetylene hydrogenation is structure sensitive. The particle size of bimetallic PdNi nanoparticles has a great impact on their catalytic performance. HRTEM images of the three catalysts and the corresponding size distribution are shown in Fig. 4 . The mean particle size of PdNi nanoparticles in Sol-PdNi/LDH, L-PdNi/MMO, and I-PdNi/MMO catalyst was 3.0nm, 3.9nm, and 4.5nm, respectively. The order of particle size is well consistent with that of catalytic activity. It is worth mentioning that the amount of particles larger than 5.5nm in Sol-PdNi and I-PdNi catalyst accounts for 5% and 20%, respectively. However, such big particles are rarely found in L-PdNi catalyst. The narrower size distribution in L-PdNi catalyst prepared by the LDH precursor method indicates more uniform dispersion, which can be ascribed to the lattice orientation and net trap effect of the NiMgAl-LDH precursor [9]. Specifically, in the NiMgAl-LDH precursor, Ni2+, Mg2+, and Al3+ cations uniformly occupied the octahedral holes in the brucite-like layer, resulting in the atomic level dispersion. During the impregnation process, PdCl4 2− adsorbs on LDH layer with positive charge, realizing uniform dispersion of PdCl4 2−. Upon co-reduction, Pd2+ even a small part of reduced Pd particles migrate to the regions near Ni2+ to achieve redispersion. Therefore, the formed PdNi nanoparticles possess high dispersion. Meanwhile, the net trap structure of MgO and Al2O3 microcrystals stemming from LDH precursor provided fixed position for the PdNi nanoparticles, leading to the stability of dispersion [9]. The HRTEM image and particle size frequency distribution histogram of Sol-PdNi/LDH catalyst after thermal treatment are shown in Fig. S3. As expected, the particle size sharply increases from 3.0 to 7.1nm. Compared with I-PdNi-MMO and L-PdNi-MMO catalyst, the Sol-PdNi-MMO catalyst with larger metal particles exhibits both lower activity and selectivity, which suggests smaller metal particles could enhance the catalytic performance in partial hydrogenation of acetylene. XPS data in Fig. 5 are used to detect the surface composition of catalyst samples and to illustrate the interplay between Pd and Ni in catalysts [31]. The Pd 3d spectrum shows two main peaks in I-Pd catalyst, and the binding energy (BE) at around 335 and 340.5eV are in accordance with the literature values for Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 of Pd0 supported on hydrotalcite-like structure [32] (the preparations of I-Pd and I-Ni catalysts were clearly illustrated in Supplementary Material). In the case of I-PdNi catalyst, the Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 peaks have almost no shift compared to monometallic I-Pd catalyst. However, obvious shift is found in Sol-PdNi catalyst (+0.6eV) and L-PdNi catalyst (+0.3eV), indicating the existence of electronic interaction between Pd and Ni in these catalysts. In principle, both initial and final state effects can be responsible for the BE shifts. The former includes metal oxidation, charge transfer, polarization, etc., while the final state effects are caused by screening and delocalization of the hole formed during the photoionization of the core electrons [33,34]. Based on the initial state effect, the palladium atoms in bimetallic PdNi nanoparticles were negatively charged due to the difference of electronegativity between Pd (2.2) and Ni (1.8) [35], which was consistent with the quantum chemical calculations [36]. This might weaken the adsorption strength of ethylene leading to the higher ethylene selectivity. As for the final state effects, the filling of the valence d-band led to a screening of the core hole, causing the Pd 3d spectra to be shifted to higher BE compared to elemental palladium [37]. Besides, the particle size also influence the shift of BE. Smaller particles usually contribute to positive shift of BE [38]. Therefore, the positive shifts of the bimetallic L-PdNi and Sol-PdNi catalysts are due to a dominance of final state screening effect and small particle size effect. The above results clearly showed that the strength of electronic interaction between Pd and Ni followed the order Sol-PdNi>L-PdNi>I-PdNi. As explained, the electronic effect could change the adsorption/desorption properties of hydrogen over the surface of catalysts, affecting the formation of β-PdH in catalysts. The formation of β-PdH could restrain excessive hydrogenation and the amount of β-PdH is in contrast to the order of the strength of electronic interaction between Pd and Ni. Thus the selectivity of ethene over L-PdNi is higher than that over I-PdNi catalyst. Although the electronic effect between Pd and Ni is the strongest among the three catalysts, the selectivity of Sol-PdNi catalyst is the lowest due to the nature of the support. The specific reason will be revealed by NH3-TPD analysis. As shown in Fig. 5B, the BE at around 851.6eV in I-Ni catalyst is in accordance with the literature values for Ni 2p3/2 of Ni0 [39]. Compared with monometallic I-Ni catalyst, the content of Ni0 significantly increases in bimetallic catalysts, resulting from the presence of Pd which could inhibit the oxidation of reduced Ni0 to Ni2+ by air to some extent. Similar with Pd 3d peaks, obvious shift of Ni0 peaks to higher BE is also observed in L-PdNi (+0.5eV) and Sol-PdNi (+0.7eV) catalysts compared to I-PdNi catalyst, which further indicates stronger interaction between Pd and Ni. The peaks at 854.7eV, 856eV, 858eV, and 862.3eV were ascribed to Ni 2p3/2 of Ni2+-O lattice species, NiO, NiAl2O4, and satellite peaks, respectively [40]. It should be noticed that the peak of Ni2+-O lattice species and NiAl2O4 spinel could not be observed in Sol-PdNi catalyst without thermal treatment. 3.3.2 In situ CO-IR analysis IR spectroscopy of CO chemisorption can used to probe the geometric and electronic structures of bimetallic surfaces. Fig. 6 compares IR spectroscopy of CO adsorbed on Sol-PdNi, L-Pd-Ni, and I-PdNi catalysts. It is known that CO adsorption on Pd surface was in linear (>2000cm−1) and multi-coordinated (<2000cm−1) modes. The peak area ratio of linear adsorbed CO (A l) to multi-coordinated CO (A m) is obviously different of the three catalysts. A l/A m of Sol-PdNi catalyst (0.53) is much higher than that of L-PdNi catalyst (0.28) and I-PdNi catalyst (0.12). The full width at half-maximum (FWHM) ratio values (W l/W m) of Sol-PdNi, L-PdNi, and I-PdNi catalysts are 1.00, 0.57, and 0.18, respectively. The value of A l/A m and W l/W m of the catalysts indicate a change in the adsorption state of CO, which suggests the effect of Ni separating the contiguous Pd sites is most prominent in Sol-PdNi catalyst, followed by L-PdNi catalyst. H2-TPD can provide some lights on the differences in metal/support interaction and electronic properties of supported metal particles [41]. H2-TPD profiles are presented in Fig. 7 , pertinent to H2 release and T max values. Each desorption profile contains a common desportion peak at T ∼175°C due to the release of chemisorbed H2 from Pd surface. Compared with I-PdNi catalyst, an obvious peak shifting toward lower temperature is observed in the catalyst of L-PdNi, suggesting easier desorption of H2 over L-PdNi catalyst because of the small particle size and narrow size distribution of metals in L-PdNi catalyst. Being Pd is in reduced state, where the adsorbed H2 species on Pd surface is dissociated into H atoms and then transport to metal–metal interface, where H atoms are recombined into H2. It is notable that the profile of L-PdNi catalyst characterized with presence of discernible higher temperature release H2 at T ∼290°C, which further indicates an intimate metal–metal interaction in the catalyst prepared by the LDH precursor method. 3.3.3 Acidity of the supports and electronic structure of the catalysts According to the literatures, surface acidity of the support could decrease the selectivity to alkene [42]. Therefore, NH3-TPD was performed to measure the acidity of MgAl-LDH and MgAl-MMO and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . The position and the area of the desorption peak are directly correlated with the acid strength and the acid amount, respectively [43]. The NH3 desorption profiles of the MgAl-LDH exhibit four distinct desorption processes: the NH3 desorption peak at approximately 91°C is assigned to the NH3 desorption by weak acid sites; peaks at around 229 and 324°C are corresponded to medium acid sites; the one centered at high temperature (441°C) is originated from the strong acid sites on the support [44,45]. Since the NH4+ ions fixed on the Brønsted acid sites are less thermally stable than the coordinated NH3 molecules bounded to the Lewis acid sites, it could be deduced that the desorption peak at low temperature was assigned to NH4+ ions bounding to the Brønsted acid sites, while the desorption peak at high temperature is associated with NH3 molecules fixing on the Lewis acid sites [46]. Compared with MgAl-LDH support, MgAl-MMO support presents a broad weak desorption peak. Moreover, the overall curve shifts toward the low temperature region, indicating that the strength of acid sites on MgAl-MMO is weaker than that on MgAl-LDH. The smaller peak area of MgAl-MMO also implies fewer acid sites on this support. To elucidate the relationship between selectivity and the properties of catalyst, C2H4-TPD was performed over I-PdNi and L-PdNi catalysts and the results are shown in Fig. 9 . The desorption peaks of C2H4 from Pd surface appear at different temperatures depending on the characteristic modes. In Fig. 9, both of the catalysts show two major peaks. The lower temperature peak is assigned to π-bonded ethene, which is weakly adsorbed and consequently desorbs without decomposition [47]. The higher temperature peak is due to stronger adsorbed species involving di-σ-bonded ethene and triply bound species as well as ethylidyne [48]. To achieve high ethene selectivity, the formed ethene should be desorbed without being further hydrogenated to ethane. Compared with I-PdNi catalyst, the peaks shift to lower temperature by approximately 15°C, indicating that the desorption of ethene from the surface of L-PdNi is easier than that from I-PdNi, which is in agreement with the XPS discussion. 3.3.4 Stability of the activity Stability is another important parameter to evaluate catalyst. Time-on-stream analysis of the catalysts in partial hydrogenation of acetylene was investigated at 70°C with the relative pressure of 0.2MPa for up to 40h as shown in Fig. 10 . The activity of Sol-PdNi catalyst maintains the highest level during initial 8h and then sharply decreases to 50% after reaction for 40h. The activity of I-PdNi catalyst also decreases significantly from 86 to 60%. However, L-PdNi catalyst maintains a relative stable state, the activity only decreases to a slight extent during the entire process. This stable activity of L-PdNi catalyst could be ascribed to preferable structure stability and low carbon deposition. 3.3.5 Particle size and carbon deposits of the used catalysts The stability of structure could be reflected by the aggregation extent of active metals [49]. HRTEM images of the used catalysts are shown in Fig. S4. The metal particle size of all the three catalysts increased with different degrees after long time reaction. The Sol-PdNi catalyst had the maximum extent of aggregation and the mean size of particles increased from 3.0 to 5.7nm. Some of the particles were even larger than 10nm. The mean size of PdNi particles in the used I-PdNi catalyst was 5.0nm, and the ratio of particles larger than 6nm increased significantly. However, the mean size of PdNi particles in the used L-PdNi catalyst only increased to 4.2nm. Preferable structure stability of the L-PdNi catalyst could be due to the net trap effect of MgAl-MMO microcrystals stemming from LDH precursor which provided fixed positions for stabilizing PdNi nanoparticles during the reaction [9]. Carbon deposit is usually regarded as another important factor to decrease the activity of catalysts. Briefly, lesser the carbon catalyst deposited, the better stability they showed during hydrogenation [50]. TPO experiments were taken to measure the carbon deposit of these three PdNi catalysts after usage, and the result is shown in Fig. S5. Although TPO cannot provide any direct information on the chemical nature of the carbonaceous deposits, it can provide information about the quantity and structure of carbon (i.e., whether amorphous or polymeric) and its location (i.e., on the support or on the metal). The profiles indicated three peaks (i.e., three coke species) [51]. The peaks centered at 210–250°C suggest that the coke was located on the metal or within close proximity and implies that the metal assisted with combustion. This coke was harmless to the reaction [52]. Peaks located at 300 and 370°C can be associated with the combustion of amorphous coke, a precursor of graphitic carbon that has a structure of oligomeric hydrocarbon, C x H y . In general, this graphitic carbon held firmly on the support. Its accumulation provokes considerable steric hindrance, which reduces the availability of hydrogen and acetylene [53]. The results of TPO illustrated that all the three catalysts had excellent resistance against carbonaceous deposits. Therefore, deactivation of the I-PdNi and Sol-PdNi catalysts could mainly be ascribed to the increase of PdNi particle size caused by the migration and aggregation during reaction process. 4 Conclusions A highly selective and stable bimetallic PdNi catalyst was designed and prepared by a LDH precursor route. By introducing Ni2+ into the layer of LDHs, followed by the impregnation of PdCl4 2−, the PdCl4 2−/NiMgAl-LDH catalyst precursor was obtained. Upon thermal reduction, the catalyst precursor was transformed into bimetallic PdNi/MgAl-MMO (L-PdNi) catalyst. Uniform dispersion of Ni2+ and the electrostatic interaction between PdCl4 2− and NiMgAl-LDH layers enable high dispersion of bimetallic PdNi nanoparticles. As comparison, the PdNi catalyst was also prepared by the co-impregnation and sol-immobilization method, denoted as Sol-PdNi and I-PdNi, respectively. In partial hydrogenation of acetylene, the activity was in the order of Sol-PdNi>L-PdNi>I-PdNi which was consistent with the mean size of PdNi nanoparticles. However, the ethene selectivity was in the order of L-PdNi>I-PdNi>Sol-PdNi. Preferable selectivity of L-PdNi catalyst was mainly ascribed to stronger interaction between Pd and Ni, which changed the adsorption/desorption properties of hydrogen over the surface of catalyst and therefore decreased the formation of β-PdH and restrained excessive hydrogenation. Furthermore, because of preferable structure stability, this PdNi catalyst derived from LDH precursor possessed higher stability of activity. Preferable structure stability of the catalyst could be due to the net trap effect of MgAl-MMO microcrystals stemming from LDH precursor which provided fixed positions for the PdNi nanoparticles during the reaction. Thus, the bimetallic PdNi catalyst prepared by the LDH precursor route with advantages of high selectivity and stability shows a great potential in the effective utilization of chemical resources. coredata.dc:description: An effective and versatile synthetic approach is presented to prepare highly selective and stable bimetallic PdNi catalyst for selective hydrogenation of acetylene. NiMgAl-layered double hydroxide (LDH) was synthesized by separate nucleation and aging steps, followed by the introduction of PdCl4 2− to obtain the catalyst precursor. The positive charge of NiMgAl-LDH layer offers an opportunity to realize uniform dispersion of PdCl4 2−, which facilitates the formation of bimetallic PdNi nanoparticles. Upon thermal reduction of PdCl4 2−/NiMgAl-LDH precursor, highly dispersed bimetallic PdNi/MgAl-MMO catalyst was obtained. As comparison, MMO-supported PdNi catalyst was also prepared by the co-impregnation and sol-immobilization method. The catalyst derived from LDH precursor exhibited much higher activity and selectivity toward ethene than that prepared by other two methods, which could be attributed to smaller metal particle size and stronger interaction between two metals. Furthermore, because of preferable structure stability, this catalyst also possessed higher stability of activity. Preferable structure stability of the catalyst could be due to the net trap effect of MgAl-MMO microcrystals stemming from LDH precursor, which provided fixed positions for the PdNi nanoparticles during the reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Highly selective and stable PdNi catalyst derived from layered double hydroxides for partial hydrogenation of acetylene
